title: Somewhat Against Psychiatric Conditions As Domestication Failure
summary:
Key ideas
- Benitez-Burraco and Lattanzi theorize that autism and schizophrenia are anomalies in the human self-domestication process
- Similar changes occur in any species bred for tameness due to changes in the embryonic neural crest
- BBL argues that autistic people are “undomesticated humans” and schizophrenics are “hyperdomesticated humans”
- The theory proposes that domesticated animals are friendlier and less aggressive, but schizophrenics aren't friendlier or less aggressive, unlike domesticated animals

Key learnings
- Domestication seems to be linked to a physiological social/trust system that determines the level of trust and sociability and is linked to ear and nose shape
- Autism, schizophrenia, and Williams Syndrome all affect that system in different ways
- Embryology can help pinpoint the particular systems involved in autism and schizophrenia

Key questions
- How could embryological research help pinpoint the particular systems involved in autism and schizophrenia?
- Could a version of Williams Syndrome that only deleted WBSCR17 keep the behavioral and physiologic changes but not much else?
